Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: MultiSpot - Closing the power-delivery/heat-removal cycle for heterogeneous multiscale systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The semiconductor industry is poised to continue the historic Moore's law trend of doubling the level of integration every 18 months, even as the virtuous cycle benefits of Dennard scaling are quickly vanishing. Once devices no longer scale laterally, one way to continue to increase areal density is to use 3D integration. The main objective of the current project, called the MultiSpot project, is to provide fundamental solutions to the problem of 3D-IC power wall. These solutions could have a deep impact on the semiconductor industry, and thus the society as a whole by providing a path forward for Moore's law to take advantage of the third dimension. The project will also lead to new research infrastructure exemplified by the several high-impact architecture modeling tools for power and thermals previously developed by the PIs, such as HotSpot, HotLeakage VoltSpot, and ArchFP that have enabled extensive research at academic institutions and industry in the past.

One approach is to provide very low impedance paths from the interior of the volume to the outside for power in addition to heat removal. A different dual use for microchannels is to modify their walls to create supercapacitors that can be useful to store extra charge to combat power brownouts or boost operations. An alternative method to address the power delivery volumetric/areal mismatch is voltage stacking, in which the different layers in a 3D-IC stack are electrically connected in series, instead of in parallel as in a conventional approach. MultiSpot proposes practical methods to complement and assist the implicit regulation of voltage stacking with the explicit regulation of multi-output switched-capacitor ladder networks. The project also considers cross-layer aspects, such as details of embedded capacitor technologies, the architectural implications of homogeneous vs. heterogeneous 3D-IC solutions, the modeling of power delivery and heat removal at the architecture level, and validation through modeling and simulations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Moore's law is coming to an end not only because of a slowdown in scaling of the minimum feature sizes of an integrated circuit (IC), less than 10nm in current technologies, but also because of the increased power density and associated heat dissipation challenges associated with cramming more and more devices on a chip. The logical expansion in the third (vertical) dimension (three-dimensional IC, or 3D-IC) in order to compensate for the slowdown in lateral dimension scaling is only exacerbating these power delivery and thermal challenges, also known as the "power wall."

The main objective of the MultiSpot project was to provide fundamental solutions to the 3D-IC power wall that are also practical. The main hypotheses of the project were: 1) comprehensive solutions need to address both heat removal and power delivery synergistically, closing the energy cycle, 2) the brain is one of the main energy consumers in the body that also needs to be efficiently cooled, it has the same volumetric vs. areal mismatch as future 3D-ICs, and biology can provide useful inspiration for the problem at hand, and 3) design space exploration of the power delivery/heat removal problem requires tools that can model heterogeneous systems.

The fact that power delivery and heat removal form an energy "cycle" might seem obvious, but the conventional design methodologies treat them separately, using separate design teams, different tools, etc., despite the fact that what goes in (power delivery), must come out (heat removal), thus there should be many opportunities for co-designing the power delivery and heat removal solutions. Based on this observation the MultiSpot project was based on two synergistic tools, called HotSpot and VoltSpot, for modeling thermals and power delivery, respectively. The two tools share similar algorithmic bases, modeling strategies, and user interfaces. The work on thermal modeling, started more than a decade ago, was awarded the Influential ISCA conference Paper Award in 2018.

An important observation made at the beginning of the MultiSpot project was that 3D-IC solutions have a fundamental dimensional mismatch between power consumption that happens in the entire volume (3D), and the heat removal that (conventionally) happens only at the external surface (2D). Getting inspiration from biology (e.g. mammals regulate their temperature by regulating their blood flow near the surface/skin) it was natural to investigate microfluidic cooling (the microchannels serving the role of blood vessels) as a "natural" way to address this fundamental dimensional mismatch. To address the similar mismatch for power delivery we investigated the use of voltage stacking, thus trading off increased voltage for reduced current, in a similar way to the use of high-voltage power lines to reduce power losses over long distances in our everyday world.

The above mentioned ideas would have remained just interesting ideas in the absence of the underlying tools, HotSpot and VoltSpot, that we developed and made publicly available to a wide audience (our thermal papers have more than 5000 citations combined). The latest HotSpot release will have all the above features included, with the most important being the addition of a flexible and dynamic microfluidic cooling model in addition to the previous power and thermal model. Before our original HotSpot tool designers were generally using a fixed (steady-state) power model and a fixed (worst case) thermal model. With our original HotSpot tool we introduced the capability of having a dynamic (in space and time) power model, while still having a fixed thermal model. The key original contribution was to create a "thermal circuit" model of the thermal solution in which thermal "current sources" (the heat dissipation elements) are combined with thermal resistances and capacitances distributed in space in order to use simulation to determine the spatial and temporal thermal "landscape." With the MultiSpot project we also introduced the possibility of having a flexible thermal model by modulating the direction and rate of the microfluidic flow. We model the microfluidic flow with a "fluid flow" circuit in which the pumps are the "sources" and the microchannels are the "flow resistances", thus we can solve the three intertwined "circuits" (electrical, thermal, microfluidic) with similar solvers.

The research outcomes of this project should make an impact on the adoption of microfluidic cooling for 3D IC, which in turn will allow for continuous progress in reinterpreting "Moore's law" to include 3D solutions. Through hiring of the graduate students involved with the project, companies can get access to the technology through human resources, while the patents issued to the PIs can make an impact through licensing. If microfluidic cooling becomes successful, and if this helps Moore's law continuing for the foreseeable future by means of 3D integration, the impact on society will be huge by allowing the current rate of progress in the electronic industry to continue unabated.
